Package org.jconfigurations

Contains the annotations that mark a field as a target for its respective Configurator, and also contains the framework's exception class.

See: Description

  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    ConfigurationException
    Base exception class.
  • Annotation Types Summary 
    Annotation Type Description
    CollectionConfiguration
    The CollectionConfigurator acts upon fields marked with @CollectionConfiguration.
    Configuration
    The BasicConfigurator acts upon fields marked with Configuration.
    MapConfiguration
    The MapConfigurator acts upon fields marked with @MapConfiguration.
    Name
    The configuration's name as expected in the configuration source.
    Required
    Indicates that the field's configuration must be provided.

Package org.jconfigurations Description

 Contains the annotations that mark a field as a target for its respective Configurator, and also contains 
 the framework's exception class.
 
 Each annotation is developed together with its respective Configurator that "owns" it, meaning that no other 
 Configurator should be triggered by the presence of said annotation if it does not "own" it. Eg.: marking a 
 field with Configuration will force the BasicConfigurator into action for the field, but 
 such is not the case for the RequiredConfigurator because field will be ignored by the latter.
In order to use these features, you need to:
  1. Annotate a class' field accordingly with eg. Configuration.
  2. Instantiate the annotation's respective configurator, eg. BasicConfigurator when using Configuration, by providing an adequate ConfigurationSource.
  3. Invoke the Configurator's configure(Object) method and pass an instance of the class as input.
An alternative for step 2 would be to always use the JConfigurator and never worry about having the right Configurator for the annotations you're working with, because internally it delegates to a Configurator chain containing all of the framework's configurators.
